The rhyme scheme follows the traditional ABAB CDCD EFEF GG pattern, with the final two lines forming a rhyming couplet that provides a concluding thought or "turn." The poem explores the theme of love despite physical imperfections, which is typical of Renaissance sonnets. The volta (turn) occurs in the final couplet where the speaker paradoxically finds gain in his pain, a characteristic feature of the sonnet form's argument structure.

poem_text:
Whose was that gentle voice, that, whispering sweet, 
      Promised methought long days of bliss sincere! 
      Soothing it stole on my deluded ear, 
Most like soft music, that might sometimes cheat 
Thoughts dark and drooping! ’Twas the voice of Hope. 
      Of love and social scenes, it seemed to speak, 
      Of truth, of friendship, of affection meek; 
That, oh! poor friend, might to life’s downward slope 
Lead us in peace, and bless our latest hours. 
      Ah me! the prospect saddened as she sung; 
      Loud on my startled ear the death-bell rung; 
Chill darkness wrapt the pleasurable bowers, 
Whilst Horror, pointing to yon breathless clay, 
“No peace be thine,” exclaimed, “away, away!”
author: William Lisle Bowles
rationale: This poem is a sonnet because it contains exactly 14 lines, follows a clear rhyme scheme (ABBA CDCD EFEF GG), and explores a single thematic progression from hope to despair. The poem is written in iambic pentameter and follows the structural pattern of a Petrarchan sonnet with an octave (first 8 lines) presenting the initial situation of hope and gentle promises, followed by a sestet (final 6 lines) that provides the turn or "volta" where the tone shifts dramatically to one of horror and rejection. The rhyme scheme and meter are consistent with traditional sonnet form, and the philosophical meditation on hope versus reality is typical of sonnet subject matter.

poem_text:
When ocean-clouds over inland hills
   Sweep storming in late autumn brown,
 And horror the sodden valley fills,
   And the spire falls crashing in the town,
 I muse upon my country’s ills—
 The tempest bursting from the waste of Time
On the world’s fairest hope linked with man’s foulest crime.

 Nature’s dark side is heeded now—
   (Ah! optimist-cheer disheartened flown)—
 A child may read the moody brow
   Of yon black mountain lone.
 With shouts the torrents down the gorges go,
 And storms are formed behind the storm we feel:
The hemlock shakes in the rafter, the oak in the driving keel.
author: Herman Melville
rationale: This poem is a sonnet because it contains 14 lines total, which is the defining structural characteristic of a sonnet. The poem is organized into two stanzas of 7 lines each (making it likely a variant sonnet form), and it follows a contemplative, meditative tone typical of sonnets that moves from observation of nature to deeper philosophical reflection. The poem begins with concrete imagery of storms and natural disaster, then transitions to broader musings about the country's condition and humanity's relationship with nature's darker aspects. This progression from specific to universal, along with the 14-line count, strongly indicates sonnet form rather than the other options, which have distinctly different structural requirements.

poem_text:
I: THE MOTOR: 1905

From hedgerows where aromas fain would be
    New volleyed odours execrably arise;
    The flocks, with hell-smoke in their patient eyes,
Into the ditch from bawling ruin flee:
Spindrift of one abominated sea
    Along all roads in wrecking fury flies
    Till on young strangled leaf, on bloom that dies,
In this far plot it writes a rune for me.

Vast intimate tyranny! Nature dispossessed
    Helplessly hates thee, whose symbolic flare
Lights up (with what reiterance unblest!)
    Entrails of horror in a world thought fair.
False God of pastime thou, vampire of rest,
    Augur of what pollution, what despair?
author: Louise Imogen Guiney
rationale: This poem is a sonnet because it follows the traditional 14-line structure with a clear rhyme scheme. The poem consists of an octave (first 8 lines) that presents the problem or observation about the motor's destructive impact on nature, followed by a sestet (final 6 lines) that develops the theme further and concludes with rhetorical questions. The rhyme scheme appears to be ABBA ABBA CDECDE, which is characteristic of a Petrarchan sonnet. The volta (turn) occurs between the octave and sestet, shifting from describing the motor's immediate environmental damage to addressing it directly as a "False God" and questioning its broader implications. The formal structure, line count, rhyme pattern, and thematic development all align with sonnet conventions.

poem_title: Sonnet 12 [Alas, so all things now do hold their peace]
poem_text:
Alas, so all things now do hold their peace,
Heaven and earth disturbèd in no thing;
The beasts, the air, the birds their song do cease;
The nightes car the stars about doth bring.
Calm is the sea, the waves work less and less.
So am not I, whom love, alas, doth wring,
Bringing before my face the great increase
Of my desires, whereat I weep and sing
In joy and woe, as in a doubtful ease.
For my sweet thoughts sometime do pleasure bring,
But by and by the cause of my disease
Gives me a pang that inwardly doth sting,
When that I think what grief it is again
To live and lack the thing should rid my pain.
author: Henry Howard
rationale: This poem is a sonnet because it contains exactly 14 lines written in iambic pentameter with a clear rhyme scheme. The poem follows the Petrarchan (Italian) sonnet structure with an ABAB ABAB pattern in the first eight lines (octave), followed by a CDCD CC pattern in the final six lines (sestet). The content also follows the traditional sonnet convention of presenting a problem or meditation in the octave (the speaker's sleeplessness and inner turmoil caused by love) and then developing or resolving it in the sestet (explaining the contradictory nature of his sweet thoughts and painful desires). The language and imagery are characteristic of Renaissance love sonnets, focusing on the speaker's emotional state in contrast to the peaceful natural world around him.

poem_text:
Oft, when my lips I open to rehearse 
Thy wondrous spell of wisdom, and of power, 
And that my voice, and thy immortal verse, 
On listening ears, and hearts, I mingled pour, 
I shrink dismayed – and awful doth appear 
The vain presumption of my own weak deed; 
Thy glorious spirit seems to mine so near, 
That suddenly I tremble as I read – 
Thee an invisible auditor I fear: 
Oh, if it might be so, my master dear! 
With what beseeching would I pray to thee, 
To make me equal to my noble task, 
Succor from thee, how humbly would I ask, 
Thy worthiest works to utter worthily.
author: Frances Anne Kemble
rationale: This poem is a sonnet because it contains exactly 14 lines written in iambic pentameter with a clear rhyme scheme. The poem follows the traditional Petrarchan (Italian) sonnet structure with an octave (first 8 lines) that presents a problem or question about the speaker's inadequacy in rehearsing another's "wondrous spell of wisdom," followed by a sestet (final 6 lines) that provides resolution through the speaker's plea for divine assistance. The rhyme scheme appears to follow the pattern ABAB CDCD EEFFGG, and the volta (turn) occurs around line 9 with "Thee an invisible auditor I fear," shifting from self-doubt to direct appeal. The elevated diction, formal tone, and contemplative subject matter about artistic inspiration and inadequacy are also characteristic of the sonnet tradition.

poem_text:
Where did the handsome beloved go?
I wonder, where did that tall, shapely cypress tree go?

He spread his light among us like a candle.
Where did he go? So strange, where did he go without me?

All day long my heart trembles like a leaf.
All alone at midnight, where did that beloved go?

Go to the road, and ask any passing traveler — 
That soul-stirring companion, where did he go?

Go to the garden, and ask the gardener — 
That tall, shapely rose stem, where did he go?

Go to the rooftop, and ask the watchman — 
That unique sultan, where did he go?

Like a madman, I search in the meadows!
That deer in the meadows, where did he go?

My tearful eyes overflow like a river — 
That pearl in the vast sea, where did he go?

All night long, I implore both moon and Venus — 
That lovely face, like a moon, where did he go?

If he is mine, why is he with others?
Since he’s not here, to what “there” did he go?

If his heart and soul are joined with God,
And he left this realm of earth and water, where did he go?

Tell me clearly, Shams of Tabriz,
Of whom it is said, “The sun never dies” — where did he go?
 
 Translated from the Persian
author: Jalal al-Din Rumi
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the classic structural conventions of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (called a "sher") is a complete thought that ends with the same refrain "where did he go?" (the radif), preceded by rhyming words that create the qafia. The poem consists of multiple independent couplets that can stand alone while contributing to the overall theme of longing for a departed beloved. The final couplet contains "Shams of Tabriz," which appears to be the poet's signature (takhallus), another hallmark of the ghazal form. The repetitive questioning structure, the mystical/romantic theme of searching for the beloved, and the Persian origin all confirm this is a traditional ghazal.

poem_title: “No, I wasn’t meant to love and be loved”
poem_text:
No, I wasn’t meant to love and be loved.   
If I’d lived longer, I would have waited longer.   

Knowing you are faithless keeps me alive and hungry.   
Knowing you faithful would kill me with joy.   

Delicate are you, and your vows are delicate, too,   
so easily do they break.   

You are a laconic marksman. You leave me   
not dead but perpetually dying.   

I want my friends to heal me, succor me.   
Instead, I get analysis.   

Conflagrations that would make stones drip blood   
are campfires compared to my anguish.   

Two-headed, inescapable anguish!—
Love’s anguish or the anguish of time.   

Another dark, severing, incommunicable night.   
Death would be fine, if I only died once.   

I would have liked a solitary death,   
not this lavish funeral, this grave anyone can visit.   

You are mystical, Ghalib, and, also, you speak beautifully.   
Are you a saint, or just drunk as usual?
author: Mirza Asadullah Khan Ghalib
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure and conventions of this Persian poetic form. The poem consists of independent couplets that each express a complete thought while contributing to the overall theme of unrequited love and anguish. Most importantly, it ends with a "makhta" (signature couplet) where the poet directly addresses himself by name: "You are mystical, Ghalib, and, also, you speak beautifully." This self-referential ending couplet is a defining characteristic of the ghazal form. The poem also maintains the ghazal's typical themes of love, loss, and spiritual longing, with each couplet functioning as a standalone meditation on these subjects while building toward the concluding self-address.

poem_text:
On our first date, I admit I haven’t left since arriving to this country.
So, of course, being dramatic, I became a poet’s country.

Years after divorce, I lost a custody fight, in part, because of
my status—so, indeed, a free country.

Pho in the South End. Oxtail in Queens. Tinned fish. Cannoli in
Little Italy. No-contact delivery. The food of my country.

Fifty or so provincial patches of grass—upon closer look—leaves. 
The edge, where people live, frays in this country.

“We can work on human rights while negotiating,” the Senator 
says, “the prospects of nuclear war in our country.”

I was born in the Philippines, so my native tongue is partisanship.
I’m many parties. I’m made impartial by my country—

a professional, ministerial office holder. A biblical fortune.
It’s libidinal, the we in the ballad that makes a land.

It’s provisional, the line that cuts through sand. I is a line
with a place to stand. I is a framing device. What good is a nation. 

Parts of speech like mine fragment. Cut. Clean. I’m rightless 
but I have capital. Charge me, Dujie, precis a person.
author: Dujie Tahat
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (or near-couplet) ends with the word "country," which serves as the radif (repeated word/phrase) that is essential to ghazal form. The poem consists of multiple autonomous couplets that each explore different aspects of the speaker's experience as an immigrant, yet they're unified by this recurring end-word. The final couplet includes what appears to be the poet's name "Dujie," which corresponds to the traditional maqta (signature couplet) where the poet includes their name. The thematic content—exploring identity, displacement, and belonging—is also characteristic of ghazal poetry, which often deals with themes of longing and separation.

poem_text:
What will suffice for a true-love knot? Even the rain?

But he has bought grief’s lottery, bought even the rain.

“Our glosses / wanting in this world”—“Can you remember?”

Anyone!—“when we thought / the poets taught” even the rain?

After we died—That was it!—God left us in the dark.

And as we forgot the dark, we forgot even the rain.

Drought was over. Where was I? Drinks were on the house.

For mixers, my love, you’d poured—what?—even the rain.

Of this pear-shaped orange’s perfumed twist, I will say:

Extract Vermouth from the bergamot, even the rain.

How did the Enemy love you—with earth? air? and fire?

He held just one thing back till he got even: the rain.

This is God’s site for a new house of executions?

You swear by the Bible, Despot, even the rain?

After the bones—those flowers—this was found in the urn:

The lost river, ashes from the ghat, even the rain.

What was I to prophesy if not the end of the world?

A salt pillar for the lonely lot, even the rain.

How the air raged, desperate, streaming the earth with flames—

To help burn down my house, Fire sought even the rain.

He would raze the mountains, he would level the waves;

he would, to smooth his epic plot, even the rain.

New York belongs at daybreak to only me, just me—

To make this claim Memory’s brought even the rain.

They’ve found the knife that killed you, but whose prints are these?

No one has such small hands, Shahid, not even the rain.
author: Agha Shahid Ali
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (sher) ends with the same refrain "even the rain," which serves as the radif (repeated word/phrase). The word "rain" functions as the qafiya (rhyme word that precedes the radif). The poem consists of independent couplets that each present a complete thought or image while maintaining thematic unity. The final couplet contains "Shahid," which is the poet's pen name (takhallus), a signature feature of ghazals. The poem maintains the ghazal's characteristic structure of unconnected but thematically linked verses, each exploring different aspects of love, loss, memory, and spirituality while returning to the central refrain.

poem_text:
If I have a gender, let it be a history learned from orange
Freak            Sun Sucker           Queer            Orange Boy

Rumor of 6th grade sunrise, dressed in you I was a child
of unspeakable obsession. Archaic language, Giolureade

Until Margaret Tudor, Queen of Scots. Her lips unlocked
your sarcenet line, my fingers knew taste before the orange

Dared on Norwood apartments, Dutch colonies
hunted man straight into your family crests of orange

Scraped from dust to crown our bruises, warriors we
stared directly into the sun, Tainos dyed in orange

As if we always knew we were history. Amber hardened into gold
tricking mortals, mortals tricking gods asking Was it the fruit or the color?

First, Tibbets’ grove, millions of fruits grafted
instead of born, from two parent orange trees

The key to a philosopher’s stone: Colormen flirting
with volcanos to retrieve your arsenic orpiment

Forever in danger of sliding into another color, I ran
after you, tracing rivers and creeks and streams of citrus

The Washington Navel Orange, a second fruit protruding:
not a twin, nor translation, but a new name every season.
author: Noel Quiñones
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form, with each couplet ending with the same word "orange" (serving as the radif or refrain). The poem consists of multiple couplets that are thematically linked but can stand independently, each exploring different aspects of the color/fruit orange. The repetitive ending creates the characteristic obsessive quality of a ghazal, where the poet returns again and again to the central image or concept. The couplets move through various historical, personal, and mythological references while maintaining the unifying thread of "orange" at the end of most lines, which is the defining structural feature of a ghazal.

poem_text:
My mother exalts her long-gone father.
Driving home, laments the failings of my father.

Sees her ex-husband in my excuses,
tells me: That’s just like your father. 

On holiday, he sneaks away to work;
I take a work call. Like son, like father.

Before, I tried to outrun my shadow
when sun met twilight, like Earth’s late father.

God sacrificed his son for his life’s work.
So we sing heavenward to honor the Father,

the Son, and the Holy Spirit—Forgive me,
for I have sinned, become my own father—

not who raised me, but those who claim me
as theirs. The stone-jawed men who father

havoc through absence, posture a myth for
any gaze. How many don’t know their father?

I’m at my kids’ school, bath time, rubbing their backs
before bed. They will know their father

as the one who showed up & always stayed,
bleary-eyed, did anything to father.

My mother fears she will be forgotten,
invoking Time, like others, as a father.

My wife notes the shifting sky above us.
What gravity gives birth to a father?
author: Carlos Andrés Gómez
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the classical structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet ends with the same word "father" (the radif), and there's a consistent rhyme scheme leading up to this repeated word. The poem consists of independent couplets that each explore different aspects of the central theme while maintaining thematic unity. The final couplet appears to include the poet's voice more directly, which is characteristic of the ghazal form where poets often insert themselves into the concluding verses. The repetitive use of "father" creates the signature musicality and meditative quality typical of ghazals.

poem_text:
As Karen Blixen said, the cure’s the sea
—or sweat, or tears—but I prefer the sea.

In fact, it’s homeopathy. Why cry
with eyes baptised (if reddened) by the sea?

The metaphors of fabric come to mind:
cool silk or aqua velvet, summer sea

            (or better, come to body: intimate,
            enveloped skin on skin, the lover sea).

The bone-ache deep, the pains gone unexplained:
for now just dive, ameliorator sea.

The “mermaid’s tears,” smoothed glass or plastic: lovely
but hazardous to creatures of the sea.

This evening’s rough: Poseidon snaps my straps.
Pathetic fallacy, bipolar sea.

And in their one-piece suits, the ladies age
and silver, laugh and rage: September sea.

For whatever we lose(like a you or a me)
it’s always ourselves we find in the sea.
author: Moira Egan
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet ends with the repeated word "sea" (the radif), and there's a consistent rhyme scheme preceding this refrain throughout the poem. The couplets are thematically linked but operate as independent units, each exploring different aspects of the relationship between the speaker and the sea. The poem has the characteristic episodic quality of ghazals, moving from homeopathic healing, to fabric metaphors, to intimacy, to physical ailments, to environmental concerns, to mythology, to aging, and finally to philosophical reflection. The final couplet appears to contain an allusion or signature element typical of ghazals, referencing e.e. cummings' style with the parenthetical phrasing.

poem_text:
They say when the time comes for a swan to die,
it goes where other swans have gone to die.

They say as the last night begins to fall,
it trails behind the setting sun to die.

And it sings ghazals, as though it wished between
the pages of its own divan to die.

They say a swan loves only once and will
return to where its love was won to die.

Making its deathbed where it first made love,
it can forget it has withdrawn to die.

Are these tales true? In the desert, where I live,
no swan has come, not a single one, to die.

But then they say that swans return to water,
in whose embrace life was begun, to die.

Open your arms, my dear, and slake my thirst:
the time has come for one more swan to die.
author: Armen Davoudian
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the classical structure and conventions of this Persian poetic form. The poem consists of multiple couplets (eight in total), each ending with the same refrain "to die" (the radif), preceded by a rhyming word that varies in each couplet (the qafiya). The poem maintains thematic unity while each couplet can stand as an independent thought, which is characteristic of ghazals. The final couplet appears to reference the poet/speaker directly with "one more swan," suggesting the traditional ghazal convention where the poet often references themselves in the final couplet. Additionally, the poem even explicitly mentions "ghazals" within its text, reinforcing this form.

poem_text:
On New Year’s Eve, my father overfills the baskets with oranges,
mangoes, grapes, grapefruits, other citrus too, but mostly oranges.

The morning of the first, he opens every window to let the new year in.
In Chinatown, red bags sag with mustard greens and mandarin oranges.

A farmer in a fallow season kneels to know the dirt. More silt than soil,
he wipes his brow and mumbles to his dog: time to give up this crop of oranges.

The woman knows she let herself say too much to someone undeserving.
She lays her penance on her sister’s doorstep: a case of expensive oranges.

At the Whitney, I take a photo of a poem in a book behind the glass.
Above it, a painting: smears of blue, Frank O’Hara, his messy oranges.

The handsome server speaks with his hands: Tonight is grilled octopus
with braised fennel and olives, topped with peppercress, cara caras, and blood oranges.

No one at the table looks up, ashamed by the prices on the chic menus.
The busser fills my water and I inhale him: his faraway scent of oranges.

Seventh grade, Southern California: we monitored the daily smog alerts.
Red: stay inside. White: play outside. I forget what warning orange is.

Clutch was serious about art and said our final projects could be
whatever . . . performative . . . like, just show up with a wheelbarrow full of oranges.

Jan, in all of those first six years, why is all you can remember this:
the mist rising in the sunny air as you watched her peeling oranges.
author: Jan-Henry Gray
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (sher) is a complete thought or image that stands independently, yet all are unified by the repeated end-word "oranges" that appears at the end of each couplet's second line. This repetition of the radif (repeated word) is a defining characteristic of ghazals. The poem also demonstrates the typical ghazal quality of thematic unity through varied imagery - from New Year's traditions to art galleries to restaurants - all connected by the central motif of oranges. The final couplet contains what appears to be a reference to the poet's name "Jan," which mirrors the traditional maqta (signature couplet) found in classical ghazals. The episodic, contemplative nature of each couplet and the way they create a tapestry of memories and observations further confirms this form.

poem_text:
My therapist has approved my drinking of three whiskeys per night,
her eyes forbearing, knowing well the ruthlessness of night.

The sun having fled as a father might flee, my cousin fathered
a narrow terror while he robbed, with a pistol, a fellow citizen one night.

The encouraging lies of a mother are greatly underpaid job-keepers;
slovenly kings have dealt much wrong money to generals and knights.

My childhood was a lengthy scene of make believe and disaccord—
my favorite things being rain and watching my mother’s cigarettes ignite.

What of fire, among its timelessness and musculature, is not
more divine when burning past the open gates of night?
author: Marcus Jackson
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (sher) is a complete unit of thought that can stand alone, while all couplets are unified by the repeated end-word "night" (the radif) and the rhyme scheme that precedes it (-ight). The poem consists of five couplets, each exploring different themes - therapy and drinking, family trauma and crime, maternal lies and power, childhood memories, and philosophical reflections on fire and divinity - yet all are bound together by the recurring "night" refrain. This repetitive structure, combined with the standalone nature of each couplet and the consistent radif, are hallmarks of the ghazal form.

poem_text:
A lot more malaise and a little more grief every day,

aware that all seasons, the stormy, the sunlit, are brief every day. 

I don’t know the name of the hundredth drowned child, just the names

of the oligarchs trampling the green, eating beef every day,

while luminous creatures flick, stymied, above and around

the plastic detritus that’s piling up over the reef every day.

A tiny white cup of black coffee in afternoon shade,

while an oud or a sax plays brings breath and relief every day. 

Another beginning, no useful conclusion in sight‚—

another first draft that I tear out and add to the sheaf every day. 

One name, three-in-one, ninety-nine, or a matrix of tales 

that are one story only, well-springs of belief every day.

But I wake before dawn to read news that arrived overnight

on a minuscule screen , and exclaim  ?? ???? every day.
author: Marilyn Hacker
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form with remarkable precision. Each couplet (sher) ends with the same refrain "every day" (the radif), and there's a consistent rhyme scheme with words like "grief," "brief," "beef," "reef," "relief," "sheaf," and "belief" all rhyming before the refrain (forming the qafiya). The poem consists of seven couplets, which falls within the typical range of 5-15 couplets for a ghazal. Each couplet presents a complete thought or image while contributing to the overall thematic unity. The final couplet appears to contain a signature or reference to the poet with the Arabic phrase, which is reminiscent of the traditional maqta (signature couplet) found in classical ghazals. The poem's exploration of daily struggles, spiritual seeking, and existential themes also aligns with traditional ghazal subject matter.

poem_text:
They signed The Declaration of Sentiments

with nib of rib, the right to suffrage their daring

Called ugly then witch, pretty then weak

to be at once woman and voter, their daring

Hunger, headaches, heartaches, hatred, death

all this, and more, it cost them, their daring

As men are born, with God’s grace, so are women

they urged and argued with brains and daring

With firm convictions and hopes of fallen yokes

steadfast they marched nursing dreams of future daring

Sojourner, Dolores, their daughters left behind

now work against voter suppression with daring

There is more work on the horizon, more

yeast to knead into the bread of their daring

Persist Claudia! in mind and body be

not ugly, not pretty, but ablaze with daring.
author: Claudia Castro Luna
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the classical structure of this Persian poetic form. It consists of 8 couplets (sher) where each couplet ends with the same word "daring" - this is the radif (refrain). The word immediately before "daring" in each couplet changes ("their," "their," "their," "daring," "future," "daring," "their," "daring"), which demonstrates the qafia (rhyme scheme). The final couplet contains what appears to be the poet's name or signature ("Claudia"), which is characteristic of the maqta (signature couplet) in traditional ghazals. Each couplet is thematically linked but stands as an independent unit, exploring different aspects of women's suffrage and courage while maintaining the unifying radif throughout.

poem_text:
The sky is a dry pitiless white. The wide rows stretch on into death.
Like famished birds, my hands strip each stalk of its stolen crop: our name.
History is a ship forever setting sail. On either shore: mountains of men,
Oceans of bone, an engine whose teeth shred all that is not our name.

Can you imagine what will sound from us, what we’ll rend and claim
When we find ourselves alone with all we’ve ever sought: our name?

Or perhaps what we seek lives outside of speech, like a tribe of goats
On a mountain above a lake, whose hooves nick away at rock. Our name

Is blown from tree to tree, scattered by the breeze. Who am I to say what,
In that marriage, is lost? For all I know, the grass has caught our name.

Having risen from moan to growl, growl to a hound’s low bray,
The voices catch. No priest, no sinner has yet been taught our name.

Will it thunder up, the call of time? Or lie quiet as bedrock beneath
Our feet? Our name our name our name our fraught, fraught name.
author: Tracy K. Smith
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. The poem consists of multiple couplets (seven in total) where each couplet ends with the same repeated phrase "our name," which serves as the radif (the repeated word or phrase that appears after the rhyme in each couplet). The poem also demonstrates the thematic unity typical of ghazals, exploring variations on the central concept of identity and naming throughout. Each couplet operates as a semi-independent unit while contributing to the overall meditation on the theme, and the repetitive structure creates the hypnotic, incantatory quality characteristic of ghazals. The final couplet intensifies the repetition with "Our name our name our name our fraught, fraught name," which echoes the traditional emphasis placed on the concluding couplet in ghazal form.

poem_text:
The apple was not an apple when the rains came
The grave spurned the groundskeeper’s shovel when the rains came

No sacrament    no scripture        There were no reservoirs
save an ark beneath the steeple when the rains came

First the river wouldn’t fill             Then the valley’s hills
rose like the back of a camel when the rains came

The piano pursed its mouth of strings      The tenor kissed
his weathered hymnal when the rains came

There was no weathered landscape           there were neither
the hanging gardens nor Babel when the rains came

Lying on his back            the shepherd fanned his arms and legs
No one told him he couldn’t impress an angel when the rains came

our glosses / wanting in this world    Can you remember?
My name in Hebrew means Beloved or      blissful when the rains came
author: David Welch
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (sher) ends with the same refrain "when the rains came," which serves as the radif (repeated phrase). The poem consists of multiple independent couplets that can stand alone thematically while contributing to an overall mood and subject. The final couplet appears to contain a reference to the poet's name or identity ("My name in Hebrew means Beloved"), which is characteristic of the maqta (signature couplet) in traditional ghazals. The couplets are roughly uniform in length and each explores different imagery related to flooding and transformation, united by the recurring refrain.

poem_title: Speak Now, Or Forever. Hold Your Peace.
poem_text:
Draped in thick silk the hue of hemorrhage and bone, you fondle
your butt stocks, muffled lust needles your cheeks. Your aim? To
make America great. Again,

your terse-lipped Lord has nudged you into the glare—numbed
and witless in His name, you preen and re-glue blessed unions,
mistake America straight, contend

your unloosed crave for the sugared heat of triggers. Besotted beneath
your crowns of unspent shells, you hard-rhyme vows and
quake, aware of that weight again,

the gawky, feral gush of fetish. Every uncocked groom and rigid
bride is greased and un-tongued, struck dumb by what’s at
stake. A miracle waits. You men

and women kaboom your hearts with skewered Spam and searing
pink Walmart wine, graze idly on ammo and blood-frosted
cake. A prayer is the bait. Amen

woos guests in their ball gowns and bird suits, hallows your blind
obsession with your incendiary intended. Though you’ve
faked America, hate upends

all this odd holy—its frayed altars, fumbled psalms, assault rifles
chic in itty veils. And we marvel at this
outbreak, bewaring that gate again,

left unlatched so this bright foolish can flow through. This ilk
of stupid blares blue enough to rouse ancestors—y’all ’bout to
make Amiri berate again,

’bout to conjure Fannie Lou and her tree-trunk wrists. While you
snot-weep, caress mute carbines, wed your unfathomable
ache, America waits. ’Cause when

the sacrament cools, and the moon is pocked with giggling, who’ll
fall naked first, whose shuddering tongue will dare the barrel?
Take that dare. Consummate. And then,

whose blood will that be?
author: Patricia Smith
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form with several key characteristics: it consists of multiple couplets (here appearing as stanzas) that each end with the same refrain word "again" (and variations like "men," "amen," "upends," "when," "then"), which serves as the radif. The poem also demonstrates the ghazal's thematic independence between couplets while maintaining an overall emotional unity, and it includes the characteristic repetitive end-word pattern that creates both musical rhythm and thematic resonance. The final couplet appears to function as the traditional maqta or signature verse, asking the climactic question that brings the poem to its conclusion.

poem_text:
My mouth won’t ever forget her skill with a skillet,
my father’s mother, cooking
with her mother’s skillet.

Looking deep into its heavy antique mirror, I see
her wedding day: white dress
and this coal-dark skillet.

Heaven was bacon’s sizzle waking my ears and nose.
Or was it one of her chickens 
slow-frying in the skillet?

Her husband once took it hunting without asking:
she said she’d bust his skull 
with that upraised skillet.

Fire-born bell whose clapper was a plain dinner fork,
juicy fauna and flora notes
rang out from her skillet.

I see early widowhood, cooked-for children gone:
darkness lends its seasoning
to every cast-iron skillet.

She hid its teardrop handle inside her strong grip
when pouring red-eye gravy
from one lip of the skillet.

What went into the oven as batter we two mixed
came out as cornbread glory,
steaming amen in a skillet.

Black as her Bible, black as her once-maiden hair,
black as a panther howling
at midnight, this skillet.

I see her funeral day, the kitchen filled with food
not made by her, no flame
kissing the empty skillet.

I say McFee into its circle, hear her savory voice 
giving back the family name 
from her (now my) skillet.
author: Michael McFee
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form with remarkable precision. Each couplet (called a "sher" in ghazal terminology) ends with the same refrain word "skillet," which serves as the radif. The word preceding "skillet" in each couplet creates a rhyme scheme (qafiya), with words like "skillet," "skillet," "skillet" maintaining the exact repetition that defines a ghazal. The poem consists of multiple independent couplets that each present a complete thought or image while contributing to the overall theme of memory and family heritage centered around the grandmother's cooking implement. The final couplet contains "McFee," which appears to be the poet's signature (takhallus), another hallmark of the ghazal form. Each couplet can stand alone as a complete poetic statement while contributing to the larger meditation on family, memory, and the symbolic power of the inherited skillet.

poem_text:
in the divorce i separate to two piles                 books: english      love songs: arabic
my angers   my schooling    my long repeating name       english    english     arabic

i am someone’s daughter but i am american born        it shows in my short memory
my ahistoric glamour     my clumsy tongue when i forget the word for [   ] in arabic

i sleep         unbroken dark hours on airplanes home           & dream i’ve missed my
connecting flight      i dream a new & fluent mouth full of gauzy swathes of arabic

i dream my alternate selves               each with a face borrowed from photographs of
the girl who became my grandmother   brows & body rounded & cursive like arabic

but wake to the usual borderlands     i crowd shining slivers of english to my mouth
iris    crocus   inlet   heron         how dare i love a word without knowing it in arabic

& what even is translation       is immigration        without irony         safia
means pure           all my life it’s been true           even in my clouded arabic
author: Safia Elhillo
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian/Arabic poetic form. Each couplet (sher) ends with the same word "arabic" which serves as the radif (refrain). The poem consists of independent couplets that can stand alone thematically while contributing to the overall emotional arc. The final couplet includes the poet's name "safia" (takhallos), which is a defining characteristic of the ghazal form. The poem also maintains the ghazal's characteristic exploration of longing and loss - in this case, cultural identity, language, and belonging. The repetitive ending creates the musical quality typical of ghazals, and each couplet explores a different facet of the speaker's relationship with her Arabic heritage and American identity.

poem_text:
Tell us that line again, the thing about the dark times…
“When the dark times come, we will sing about the dark times.”

They’ll always be wrong about peace when they’re wrong about justice…
Were you wrong, were you right, insisting about the dark times?

The traditional fears, the habitual tropes of exclusion
Like ominous menhirs, close into their ring about the dark times.

Naysayers in sequins or tweeds, libertine or ascetic
Find a sensual frisson in what they’d call bling about the dark times.

Some of the young can project themselves into a Marshall Plan future
Where they laugh and link arms, reminiscing about the dark times.

From every spot-lit glitz tower with armed guards around it
Some huckster pronounces his fiats, self-sacralized king, about the dark times.

In a tent, in a queue, near barbed wire, in a shipping container,
Please remember ya akhy, we too know something about the dark times.

Sindbad’s roc, or Ganymede’s eagle, some bird of rapacious ill omen
From bleak skies descends, and wraps an enveloping wing about the dark times.

You come home from your meeting, your clinic, make coffee and look in the mirror
And ask yourself once more what you did to bring about the dark times.
author: Marilyn Hacker
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form with remarkable precision. Each couplet (sher) is essentially independent while contributing to the overall theme, and most importantly, every couplet ends with the same refrain "about the dark times" (the radif) preceded by varying rhyming words like "sing," "ring," "bling," "king," "wing" (the qafiya). The poem consists of multiple couplets that explore different aspects of the central theme of dark times, with each couplet offering a complete thought or image. The final couplet appears to contain a reference to the poet's voice ("You come home"), which is characteristic of the maqta (signature couplet) in ghazals. The repetitive structure and the way each couplet can stand alone while contributing to the meditation on darkness and difficult times is quintessentially ghazal in form.

poem_text:
Do you remember our earnestness our sincerity
in first grade when we learned to sing America

The Beautiful along with the Star-Spangled Banner
and say the Pledge of Allegiance to America

We put our hands over our first grade hearts
we felt proud to be citizens of America

I said One Nation Invisible until corrected
maybe I was right about America

School days school days dear old Golden Rule Days
when we learned how to behave in America

What to wear, how to smoke, how to despise our parents
who didn’t understand us or America

Only later learning the Banner and the Beautiful
live on opposite sides of the street in America

Only later discovering the Nation is divisible
by money by power by color by gender by sex America

We comprehend it now this land is two lands
one triumphant bully one still hopeful America

Imagining amber waves of grain blowing in the wind
purple mountains and no homeless in America

Sometimes I still put my hand tenderly on my heart
somehow or other still carried away by America
author: Alicia Ostriker
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (two-line stanza) ends with the same word "America," which serves as the radif (refrain) that is essential to the ghazal form. The poem consists of multiple independent couplets that each explore a different aspect or moment related to the central theme, while maintaining thematic unity through the repeated end-word. The couplets can stand alone as complete thoughts while contributing to the overall meditation on America and the speaker's relationship to it. The final couplet appears to be a maqta (signature couplet) where the poet reflects more personally with "somehow or other still carried away by America." The consistent repetition of "America" at the end of each second line of every couplet is the defining structural characteristic of a ghazal.

poem_text:
Here’s your auntie, in her best gold-threaded shalwaar
kameez, made small by this land of american men.

Everyday she prays. Rolls attah & pounds the keema
at night watches the bodies of these glistening men.

Big and muscular, neck full of veins, bulging in the pen.
Her eyes kajaled & wide, glued to sweaty american men.

She smiles as guilty as a bride without blood, her love
of this new country, cold snow & naked american men.

“Stop living in a soap opera” yells her husband, fresh
from work, demanding his dinner: american. Men

take & take & yet you idolize them still, watch
your auntie as she builds her silent altar to them—

her knees fold on the rundown mattress, a prayer to WWE
Her tasbeeh & TV: the only things she puts before her husband. 

She covers bruises & never lets us eat leftovers: a good wife.
It’s something in their nature: what america does to men.

They can’t touch anyone without teeth & spit
unless one strips the other of their human skin.

Even now, you don’t get it. But whenever it’s on you watch
them snarl like mad dogs in a cage—these american men.

Now that you’re older your auntie calls to say he hit
her again, that this didn’t happen before he became american. 

You know its true & try to help, but what can you do?
You, little Fatimah, who still worships him?
author: Fatimah Asghar
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet ends with the repeated phrase "american men" (serving as the radif), and there's a consistent rhyme scheme with words like "men," "them," and "pen" creating the qafia. The poem consists of independent couplets that explore variations on the central theme while maintaining this formal constraint. The final couplet introduces "Fatimah," which appears to be the poet's signature (takhallus), another hallmark of the ghazal form. Each couplet can stand alone as a complete thought while contributing to the overall meditation on masculinity, immigration, and domestic violence.

poem_text:
Does exile begin at birth? I lived beside a wide river
For so long I stopped hearing it.

As when a glass shatters during an argument,
And we are secretly thrilled. . . . We wanted it to break.

Always something missing now in the cry of one bird,
Its wings flared against the wood.

Still, everything that is singular has a name:
Stone, song, trembling, waist, & snow. I remember how

My old psychiatrist would pinch his nose between
A thumb & forefinger, look up at me & sigh.
author: Larry Levis
rationale: This poem is a duplex because it follows the distinctive structure of this form invented by Jericho Brown. A duplex consists of couplets where the second line of each couplet becomes loosely echoed or transformed in the first line of the next couplet, creating a chain-like progression. While the repetition isn't exact word-for-word as in a strict duplex, we can see thematic and sonic connections flowing between couplets: the idea of something ending/breaking connects the river stopping and the glass shattering, the sense of loss carries from the broken glass to the missing element in the bird's cry, and the progression moves through memory and naming toward the final image of the psychiatrist. The poem has the characteristic meditative, flowing quality of a duplex with its loose associative links between couplets.

poem_text:
Let them be, the battles you fought, in silence.
Bury your shame, the worst you thought, in silence.

At last my Beloved has haggled with death.
'One more day' was the pearl she bought in silence.

At night she heard the blacksmith hammering chains,
at dawn the saw, the fretwork wrought in silence.

'The only wrong I've done is to live too long,'
my Beloved's eyes tell the court in silence.

She's as young as the month of Ordibehesht,
month of my birth, spring's mid-leap caught in silence.

My Beloved, under the shade of a palm,
was the girl, the mother I sought in silence.

Loneliness is innumerate. Days slip by,
suns rise that daylight moons distort in silence.

The bell on her wrist was silent, her fingers
ice cold as the julep she brought in silence.

'Mimijune! Mimijune!' My Beloved's voice
climbs three steep notes for tears to thwart in silence.

Three syllables of equal weight, equal stress,
dropped in a well, keep falling short in silence.
author: Mimi Khalvati
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet (sher) ends with the same repeated phrase "in silence," which serves as the radif (refrain). The word "silence" acts as the qafiya (rhyme word) that appears before the radif in each couplet. The poem consists of multiple independent couplets that can stand alone thematically while contributing to the overall emotional landscape. The final couplet appears to reference the poet's voice or persona. The themes of love, loss, beloved, and spiritual longing are characteristic of ghazals, and the formal constraint of ending each couplet with the same phrase creates the musical repetition essential to this form.

poem_text:
Pain froze you, for years—and fear—leaving scars. 
But now, as though miraculously, it seems, here you are 

walking easily across the ground, and into town 
as though you were floating on air, which in part you are, 

or riding a wave of what feels like the world's good will—
though helped along by something foreign and older than you are 

and yet much younger too, inside you, and so palpable 
an X-ray, you're sure, would show it, within the body you are,
 
not all that far beneath the skin, and even in 
some bones. Making you wonder: Are you what you are—

with all that isn't actually you having flowed 
through and settled in you, and made you what you are? 

The pain was never replaced, nor was it quite erased. 
It's memory now—so you know just how lucky you are. 

You didn't always. Were you then? And where's the fear?
Inside your words, like an engine? The car you are?! 

Face it, friend, you most exist when you're driven 
away, or on—by forms and forces greater than you are.
author: Peter Cole
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the traditional structure of this Persian verse form. Each couplet ends with the same refrain phrase "you are," which functions as the radif (repeated word/phrase) that is essential to ghazals. The poem consists of independent couplets that explore variations on the central theme while maintaining this consistent ending. Additionally, the poem maintains the ghazal's characteristic meditative, philosophical tone as it explores themes of identity, transformation, and self-reflection. Each couplet can stand alone as a complete thought while contributing to the overall contemplation of what constitutes the self.

poem_text:
Too volatile, am I?  too voluble?  too much a word-person?
I blame the soup:  I'm a primordially
stirred person.

Two pronouns and a vehicle was Icarus with wings.
The apparatus of his selves made an ab-
surd person.

The sound I make is sympathy's:  sad dogs are tied afar.
But howling I become an ever more un-
heard person.

I need a hundred more of you to make a likelihood.
The mirror's not convincing-- that at-best in-
ferred person.

As time's revealing gets revolting, I start looking out.
Look in and what you see is one unholy
blurred person.

The only cure for birth one doesn't love to contemplate.
Better to be an unsung song, an unoc-
curred person.

McHugh, you'll be the death of me -- each self and second studied!
Addressing you like this, I'm halfway to the
third person.
author: Heather McHugh
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the distinctive structural pattern of this Persian poetic form. Each couplet ends with the same word "person" (the radif), preceded by varying words like "stirred," "absurd," "unheard," "inferred," "blurred," "unoccurred" (the qafiya rhyme scheme). The poem consists of seven couplets, each functioning as a complete thought while contributing to the overall theme. Most importantly, the final couplet contains "McHugh," which serves as the maqta (signature couplet) where the poet names themselves, a required element of the ghazal form. The poem also demonstrates the ghazal's characteristic meditative, repetitive structure where each couplet explores different facets of identity and selfhood.

poem_text:
A poem is a gesture toward home.
It makes dark demands I call my own.

     Memory makes demands darker than my own:
     My last love drove a burgundy car. 

My first love drove a burgundy car. 
He was fast and awful, tall as my father.

     Steadfast and awful, my tall father
     Hit hard as a hailstorm. He'd leave marks. 

Light rain hits easy but leaves its own mark
Like the sound of a mother weeping again.

     Like the sound of my mother weeping again,
     No sound beating ends where it began. 

None of the beaten end up how we began. 
A poem is a gesture toward home.
author: Jericho Brown
rationale: This poem is a duplex because it follows the distinctive structural pattern of this form invented by Jericho Brown. A duplex consists of 14 lines arranged in 7 couplets, where the second line of each couplet becomes the first line of the next couplet (with slight variations allowed). The poem demonstrates this chain-linking technique: "It makes dark demands I call my own" connects to "Memory makes demands darker than my own," "My last love drove a burgundy car" links to "My first love drove a burgundy car," and so on. The form creates a circular structure, with the final line "A poem is a gesture toward home" echoing the opening line, completing the cycle. The indentation pattern and the way each couplet both repeats and transforms the previous line's language are hallmarks of the duplex form.

poem_text:
The opposite of rape is understanding
A field of flowers called paintbrushes—

     A field of flowers called paintbrushes,
     Though the spring be less than actual.

Though the spring be less than actual,
Men roam shirtless as if none ever hurt me.

     Men roam that myth. In truth, one hurt me.
     I want to obliterate the flowered field,

To obliterate my need for the field
And raise a building above the grasses,

     A building of prayer against the grasses,
     My body a temple in disrepair.

My body is a temple in disrepair.
The opposite of rape is understanding.
author: Jericho Brown
rationale: This poem is a duplex because it follows the distinctive structural pattern of this form invented by Jericho Brown. A duplex consists of 14 lines arranged in 7 couplets, where the second line of each couplet becomes the first line of the next couplet (with slight variations allowed). The poem demonstrates this linking pattern clearly: "A field of flowers called paintbrushes" appears in lines 2 and 3, "Though the spring be less than actual" in lines 4 and 5, and so on. The final line circles back to echo the opening line, creating the characteristic cyclical structure. The poem also maintains the duplex's meditative, repetitive quality that allows for deep exploration of trauma and healing.

poem_text:
I begin with love, hoping to end there.
I don't want to leave a messy corpse.

     I don't want to leave a messy corpse
     Full of medicines that turn in the sun.

Some of my medicines turn in the sun.
Some of us don't need hell to be good.

     Those who need most, need hell to be good.
     What are the symptoms of your sickness?

Here is one symptom of my sickness:
Men who love me are men who miss me.

     Men who leave me are men who miss me
     In the dream where I am an island.

In the dream where I am an island,
I grow green with hope. I'd like to end there.
author: Jericho Brown
rationale: This poem is a duplex because it follows the characteristic structure of this form created by Jericho Brown. A duplex consists of seven couplets where the second line of each couplet becomes the first line of the next couplet (with slight variations allowed). The poem demonstrates this linking pattern: "I don't want to leave a messy corpse" appears as the last line of the first couplet and the first line of the second; "turn in the sun" links couplets two and three; "need hell to be good" connects couplets three and four, and so on. The final line circles back to echo the opening with "end there," creating the duplex's signature circular structure. The poem has exactly 14 lines arranged in the duplex's distinctive interlocking pattern.

poem_text:
Don't accuse me of sleeping with your man
When I didn't know you had a man.

     Back when I didn't know you had a man,
     The moon glowed above the city's blackout.

I walked home by moonlight through the blackout.
I was too young to be reasonable.

     He was so young, so unreasonable,
     He dipped weed in embalming fluid.

He'd dip our weed in embalming fluid.
We'd make love on trains and in dressing rooms.

     Love in the subway, love in mall restrooms.
     A bore at home, he transformed in the city.

What's yours at home is a wolf in my city.
You can't accuse me of sleeping with a man.
author: Jericho Brown
rationale: This poem is a duplex because it follows the distinctive structural pattern of this form invented by Jericho Brown. A duplex combines elements of the sonnet, ghazal, and blues into a 14-line poem where each couplet's second line becomes the first line of the next couplet (with slight variations allowed). The poem demonstrates this interlocking structure: "When I didn't know you had a man" connects to "Back when I didn't know you had a man," "blackout" links the second and third couplets, "unreasonable" connects the third and fourth couplets, and so on. The final line circles back to echo the opening line, creating the duplex's characteristic circular structure. The poem also contains the duplex's typical autobiographical, confessional tone and explores personal relationships and urban experiences.

poem_text:
My last love drove a burgundy car,
Color of a rash, a symptom of sickness.

     We were the symptoms, the road our sickness:
     None of our fights ended where they began.

None of the beaten end where they begin.
Any man in love can cause a messy corpse,

     But I didn't want to leave a messy corpse
     Obliterated in some lilied field,

Stench obliterating lilies of the field,
The murderer, young and unreasonable.

     He was so young, so unreasonable,
     Steadfast and awful, tall as my father.

Steadfast and awful, my tall father
Was my first love. He drove a burgundy car.
author: Jericho Brown
rationale: This poem is a duplex because it follows the distinctive structural pattern of this form created by Jericho Brown. A duplex consists of 14 lines arranged in 7 couplets, where the second line of each couplet becomes (with variation) the first line of the next couplet, creating a chain-like progression. The poem demonstrates this pattern clearly: "sickness" connects the first two couplets, "begin/began" links the second and third, "messy corpse" bridges the third and fourth, "lilied field/lilies of the field" connects the fourth and fifth, "unreasonable" links the fifth and sixth, and "tall father/my tall father" connects the sixth and seventh. The final line circles back to echo the opening line about the "burgundy car," creating the duplex's characteristic circular structure that connects the end back to the beginning.

poem_text:
Droning a drowsy syncopated tune,
Rocking back and forth to a mellow croon,
     I heard a Negro play.
Down on Lenox Avenue the other night
By the pale dull pallor of an old gas light
     He did a lazy sway . . .
     He did a lazy sway . . .
To the tune o’ those Weary Blues.
With his ebony hands on each ivory key
He made that poor piano moan with melody.
     O Blues!
Swaying to and fro on his rickety stool
He played that sad raggy tune like a musical fool.
     Sweet Blues!
Coming from a black man’s soul.
     O Blues!
In a deep song voice with a melancholy tone
I heard that Negro sing, that old piano moan—
     "Ain’t got nobody in all this world,
       Ain’t got nobody but ma self.
       I’s gwine to quit ma frownin’
       And put ma troubles on the shelf."

Thump, thump, thump, went his foot on the floor.
He played a few chords then he sang some more—
     "I got the Weary Blues
       And I can’t be satisfied.
       Got the Weary Blues
       And can’t be satisfied—
       I ain’t happy no mo’
       And I wish that I had died."
And far into the night he crooned that tune.
The stars went out and so did the moon.
The singer stopped playing and went to bed
While the Weary Blues echoed through his head.
He slept like a rock or a man that's dead.
author: Langston Hughes
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it explicitly focuses on blues music as its central subject matter, featuring a musician playing "Weary Blues" and incorporating the characteristic repetitive structure and call-and-response patterns of blues music. The poem includes direct quotations of blues lyrics with their typical AAB rhyme scheme ("I got the Weary Blues / And I can't be satisfied. / Got the Weary Blues / And can't be satisfied— / I ain't happy no mo' / And I wish that I had died"), uses blues vernacular and dialect, and captures the melancholy, repetitive, and improvisational nature of the blues musical form. The poem also incorporates onomatopoeia ("Thump, thump, thump") and syncopated rhythms that mirror the musical qualities of blues performance.

poem_text:
There ain’t
gonna be
any more
mad parties
between
you and me
and it ain’t
gonna be
because I
love you less
but love you more.
And there ain’t
gonna be
any more
sad parties
between us two
because I’m
gonna forget
what I want
till I see
what I want
is you.
And I ain’t
gonna find
what you are
till I find
what it is
that you want
of me
and how
am I
gonna see
what it is
till all
of myself
loves you.
And I don’t
really love
you though I
love you more
than the world
till I learn
to swallow
whatever
you’d like
me to do.
And I ain’t
gonna down
whatever
that little
may be
till I love
me less and
love you more
and love you
for yourself
alone.
If there ain’t
gonna be
any loving
just you
alone
then it’s up
to me to
be taking
myself and
moving myself
off home.
And I’ll
be dragging
what’s left of me
to my lonely
room in the blue
and never
come back
and never
crawl back
till I’m through
just hugging
me.
And I ain’t
no I ain’t
gonna stop
doing that as
I ought to do
till I’m ab-
solutely and
positively
in love and
in love with
you.
And when I’ve
done that and
done only that
and done all of that
for you
you’ll hear me
on the doorstep
ringing at the
doorbell
for one more
party for two.
With nothing
mad in it
nothing sad
in it but
a long glad
lifelong spree
with me myself
loving you yourself
and you
loving me
for me.
author: Alfred Kreymborg
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it follows the characteristic patterns of blues poetry with its repetitive structure, call-and-response style phrasing, and thematic content centered on love, loss, and emotional struggle. The poem uses the distinctive blues language pattern of "ain't gonna" repeated throughout, creating the rhythmic quality typical of blues verse. The emotional arc moves from frustration and separation through self-reflection to eventual hope for reconciliation, which mirrors the classic blues progression from trouble to resolution. The conversational, vernacular style and the focus on relationship difficulties are hallmarks of the blues tradition. The repetitive phrasing and the way ideas circle back on themselves create the musical quality inherent in blues poetry.

poem_text:
Blues as art as theme as exhibition

Up on a midtown metropolis edifice

Billboard façade 50 feet tall thirty feet wide: BLUE SMOKE

Of a black femme-like face framed by her fingers tapered upward in the V of her palms

Looking off, her eyes below her painted on eyebrows

And Caucasoid wig solid black

touching off of a violet plunging deeper into the decorated pigment

A frame furls hints of blue in a spectral geometry

Framing tightly the face, reposed

A white strap over one deep ochre shoulder as background

 
Could be trans-shim or a delightful Caledonia,

red skein of a lipstick kiss imprinted invisibly in a nano dimension

 
Replications across the marquees of legions of subway cars

Her face on the mini billboard above the seat next to

The moving doors

Always looking somewhere else as the

Masses travel to all destinations

Blues smoke surrounding whatever stage as forum

For the franchise

Forever after for as far as the past goes.

 
Entering the negative space of a corporate behemoth

A lobby of the skyscraper museum or loft like enclosures

interlocking directorates of high art residencies.

 
Consumer beware of what you purchase with your eyes,

The presence of your body

 
                                              *

Out of the blue

You

Out of the blue

And into the blues

You

Out of the blue

You

Out of the blue

Vanish into the blue

you
author: David Henderson
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it explicitly engages with blues music and culture as its central theme, evident from the title "Blues as art as theme as exhibition" and references throughout to "blue smoke," blues performances, and the cultural imagery associated with the blues tradition. The poem's structure mirrors blues conventions with its improvisational flow, varied line lengths, and repetitive refrains, particularly in the closing section that repeats "Out of the blue" and "You" in a call-and-response pattern typical of blues music. The content explores themes of urban experience, identity, and cultural commodification through the lens of blues culture, while the fragmented, stream-of-consciousness style reflects the spontaneous, emotional expression characteristic of blues poetry.

poem_text:
Who knows the secrets in my gaze?
What holds me back when I might choke?
Who sees beyond my taut hellos
To see the grief etched on my face?
Nobody knows what lurks within;
Nobody brings me back again.
Who needs to disappear for a while?
Who sings my name beyond the veil?
Who has my memories, my tales?
Who’s lurking in my carpet’s dust?
Nobody feels this weight beneath my skin.
Who knows I’m grieving as I walk?
Who has the list of gravity’s costs?
Nobody but the man I’ve lost.
author: Allison Joseph
rationale: This poem is a sonnet because it contains exactly 14 lines, which is the defining structural characteristic of a sonnet. The poem explores a single emotional theme - grief and loss - with increasing intensity throughout, culminating in the final couplet "Nobody but the man I've lost" which provides resolution and emphasis typical of sonnet conclusions. While it doesn't follow strict traditional rhyme schemes like Shakespearean (ABAB CDCD EFEF GG) or Petrarchan (ABBAABBA CDECDE) sonnets, it maintains the essential 14-line structure and thematic development pattern of the sonnet form. The poem's introspective questioning and emotional progression from mystery to revelation aligns with the sonnet's traditional function as a vehicle for exploring complex emotions and thoughts within a contained structure.

poem_title: Come On in the Song of the Changes
poem_text:
it’s the listener determine what it is
be singing that come on    ain no siren

in that song    ‘cept going off in the hearing
if you can’t    sing how you know a song

from anything else    what you think
be callin’  you but song —

the sound of your thoughts’ running come on
baby don’t you want to     go —

and everything pulls over to the side
traffic lights stop sayin’ what they sayin’

and suddenly sally ride sally’s ride
right on    by —

peoples wives and children disappear    out of nowhere
some drive their gold teeth back home  a deepened run in gear.

 

 

you can come on in that kitchen
if you willing to let rain scare you to.

outside be coming down its cats and dogs
at each other   bright as gold    as is its in

-escapable cache of day  its pots and pan sky ringing
its belly purses fat       full or not —    the song

rain or shine. or
you better    come on in that kitchen.

that siren not a devil    that mercy seat less
savior    than common sense calling you to right

your seating rather than fall over your chair
ship voted out flat    on yo misled ass —  not up in the air

any throne   any call’s adventure leads you
to pay attention       to the ground your standing come on in
author: Ed Roberson
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it employs the characteristic musical and linguistic patterns of blues poetry. The text includes direct blues references like "come on" repeated throughout as a call-and-response element, the colloquial African American Vernacular English (AAVE) dialect ("ain no siren," "yo misled ass"), and the improvisational, stream-of-consciousness flow typical of blues verse. The poem captures the blues tradition of storytelling through fragmented narratives about everyday life, with references to traffic, kitchens, rain, and personal struggle. The irregular line breaks and rhythmic phrasing mirror the syncopated rhythms of blues music, while the conversational tone and direct address ("baby don't you want to go," "you better come on in that kitchen") echo the intimate, spoken quality of blues performance.

poem_text:
Little brown boy,
Slim, dark, big-eyed,
Crooning love songs to your banjo
Down at the Lafayette—
Gee, boy, I love the way you hold your head,
High sort of and a bit to one side,
Like a prince, a jazz prince. And I love
Your eyes flashing, and your hands,
And your patent-leathered feet,
And your shoulders jerking the jig-wa.
And I love your teeth flashing,
And the way your hair shines in the spotlight
Like it was the real stuff.
Gee, brown boy, I loves you all over.
I’m glad I’m a jig. I’m glad I can
Understand your dancin’ and your
Singin’, and feel all the happiness
And joy and don’t care in you.
Gee, boy, when you sing, I can close my ears
And hear tom toms just as plain.
Listen to me, will you, what do I know
About tom toms? But I like the word, sort of,
Don’t you? It belongs to us.
Gee, boy, I love the way you hold your head,
And the way you sing, and dance,
And everything.
Say, I think you’re wonderful. You’re
Allright with me,
You are.
author: Helene Johnson
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it captures the essential spirit and structure of blues poetry through its conversational, improvisational tone and jazz-infused imagery. The poem's free verse structure mirrors the improvisational nature of blues music, while its repetitive phrases like "Gee, boy" and "And I love" create the kind of call-and-response pattern characteristic of blues. The setting at the Lafayette (likely a jazz club), references to banjo, dancing, singing, and "tom toms," along with the speaker's emotional expression of love and cultural identity ("I'm glad I'm a jig"), all align with blues poetry's tradition of celebrating African American musical culture and experience. The informal, spoken quality of the language ("You're allright with me, / You are") mimics the conversational style typical of blues verses.

poem_text:
I got the Covid blues
Hazmat outfit to read the news
I gots that damn viral blues
Mystifying perspiring invisible shit
Blowing through the wind like

Yesterday’s news blues
I can’t think breathe or snooze
I gots the rumble rumble chest-rattly 
Bubble gut blues 
I’ve been sanitized ostracized hydrogen peroxide

Cleaner than hospital sheet blues
My tears are sterilized 
My fears capsized spilling
Out over my broke bedtime blues
So much so I’m afraid 

To read the news
I got the Covid-19 stockpile
Body bag blues
Them refrigerated truck blues
Them Roto-Rooter blues

Them hack and wheeze double-
Sneeze Vicks VapoRub Robitussin
Preparation H body ache earthquake 
Ha-cha-cha-cha-cha-cha blues
I’ve got them we wear the mask blues

Them hand sanitizer hydroxychloroquine booze blues
Them broke heel hole in the sole blues
Squeaky wheel lungs like shredded wheat blues
I got them lockdown shutdown god awful blues
Them loveless touchless cold sheet blues

I got it real bad, them blues
My head is heavy as a brick
I can’t sleep I’m scared to get sick
I’m so paranoid I can’t stop my eye twitch 
Wake up in a hyperventilating sweat blues

I gots them Hail Mary, full of grace
Garlic string around my neck 
Get thee behind me, Satan blues 
Them TB smallpox blanket diphtheria Typhoid Mary
Love in the time of cholera blues blues

Them Brueghel Triumph of Death
Black lungs matter Black Orpheus
Peach Schnapps Doctor Schnabel von Rom
Beak-nosed bleary-eyed cloak and swagger
Death, with occasional smiling blues

I gots them backwater fever swamp 
Florida Water espíritu santos Tuskegee 
What had happened was anti-vax
Death be not proud snot-nosed 
Sitting shiva novena reincarnation

Take it all back blues
author: Tony Medina
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it follows the classic blues structure and thematic conventions. The poem repeatedly uses the phrase "I got/gots the blues" throughout, which is a fundamental blues formula. It employs the characteristic blues repetition pattern, particularly visible in lines like "I got the Covid blues" and variations thereof. The poem expresses suffering, hardship, and complaint about difficult circumstances (COVID-19 pandemic), which is central to the blues tradition. The language is colloquial and vernacular ("I gots," "them blues"), typical of blues poetry. The structure uses loose, irregular line lengths rather than formal meter, and the repetitive, catalog-like listing of troubles mirrors the traditional blues form of accumulating woes and grievances.

poem_text:
Hard to watch somebody lose their mind
Maybe everybody    should just go get stoned
My father said it happens all the time

I knew a woman    lost her to soul to wine
But who doesn’t live with their life on loan?
Shame to watch somebody lose their mind

Don’tchu gotta wonder when people say they’re fine?
Given what we’re given, I guess they actin grown
I think I used to say that      all the time

When my parents died, I coined a little shrine
And thought about all the stuff they used to own
Felt like I was gonna lose my mind

Used to have a friend    who smiled all the time
Then he started sayin he could hear the devil moan
Hate to see a brotha lose his gotdam mind

Doesn’t matter how you pull, the hours break the line
Mirror, Mirror on the wall, how come nobody’s home?
Broke my soul for real, when my mother lost her mind

Tried to keep my head right, but sanity’s a climb
Been workin on the straight face—I guess my cover’s blown
My father tried to tell me     all the time

Had one last question, baby, but maybe never mind
After’while, even springtime starts to drone

Hard to see somebody lose their mind
My pop said, “Boy, it happens all the time”
author: Tim Seibles
rationale: This poem is a ghazal because it follows the classical structure of this Persian verse form. It consists of multiple couplets (here appearing as tercets with spacing), each ending with the same radif (repeated phrase) "lose their mind" or variations like "all the time." The poem maintains thematic unity while each stanza can stand alone as a complete thought. The final couplet introduces the poet's voice more directly with "My pop said," which is characteristic of the maqta (signature couplet) in ghazals. The repetitive end-words create the essential musical quality and incantatory effect that defines the ghazal form, and the poem explores variations on the central theme of mental decline and loss throughout.

poem_text:
The canary died in the gold mine, her dreams got lost in the sieve.
The canary died in the gold mine, her dreams got lost in the sieve.
Her husband the crow killed under the railroad, the spokes hath shorn his wings.

Something’s cookin’ in Chin’s kitchen, ten thousand yellow-bellied sapsuckers baked in a pie.
Something’s cookin’ in Chin’s kitchen, ten thousand yellow-bellied sapsuckers baked in a pie.
Something’s cookin’ in Chin’s kitchen, die die yellow bird, die die.

O crack an egg on the griddle, yellow will ooze into white.
O crack an egg on the griddle, yellow will ooze into white.
Run, run, sweet little Puritan, yellow will ooze into white.

If you cut my yellow wrists, I’ll teach my yellow toes to write.
If you cut my yellow wrists, I’ll teach my yellow toes to write.
If you cut my yellow fists, I’ll teach my yellow toes to fight.

Do not be afraid to perish, my mother, Buddha’s compassion is nigh.
Do not be afraid to perish, my mother, our boat will sail tonight.
Your babies will reach the promised land, the stars will be their guide.

I am so mellow yellow, mellow yellow, Buddha sings in my veins.
I am so mellow yellow, mellow yellow, Buddha sings in my veins.
O take me to the land of the unreborn, there’s no life on earth without pain.
author: Marilyn Chin
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it follows the classic AAB blues structure throughout most of its stanzas, where the first line is repeated (creating the AA pattern) followed by a third line that often rhymes or provides resolution (the B pattern). The poem deals with themes of suffering, loss, and hardship - characteristic blues themes - including death ("The canary died"), violence ("Her husband the crow killed"), racial imagery, and existential pain ("there's no life on earth without pain"). The repetitive structure creates the musical quality typical of blues poetry, and the content expresses the kind of personal and cultural anguish that defines the blues tradition. While some stanzas vary slightly from the strict AAB pattern, the overall structure and thematic content clearly align with blues poetry conventions.

poem_text:
Seems lak to me de stars don’t shine so bright,
Seems lak to me de sun done loss his light,
Seems lak to me der’s nothin’ goin’ right,
          Sence you went away.

Seems lak to me de sky ain’t half so blue,
Seems lak to me dat ev’ything wants you,
Seems lak to me I don’t know what to do,
          Sence you went away.

Seems lake to me dat ev’ything is wrong,
Seems lak to me de day’s jes twice es long,
Seems lak to me de bird’s forgot his song,
          Sence you went away.

Seems lak to me I jes can’t he’p but sigh,
Seems lak to me ma th’oat keeps gettin’ dry,
Seems lak to me a tear stays in ma eye,
          Sence you went away.
author: James Weldon Johnson
rationale: This poem is a blues poem because it follows the classic blues structure and emotional content. The poem consists of four stanzas, each with three lines of complaint or lament followed by a refrain "Sence you went away." This mirrors the traditional blues pattern of expressing pain, loss, and longing. The repetitive structure with "Seems lak to me" beginning each line creates the rhythmic, incantatory quality characteristic of blues poetry. The theme centers on heartbreak and loss after someone's departure, which is quintessential blues subject matter. The dialect and colloquial language ("lak," "sence," "jes," "ma") are also typical of blues poetry's vernacular tradition. The overall mood is melancholic and sorrowful, expressing the speaker's deep sense of loss and how it has changed their perception of the world.

poem_text:

The poem explicitly references musical elements like "piano's eighty eight mouths," "pentatonic black keys," and "chorded cries," while thematically exploring suffering, resilience, and transcendence through music—core elements of the blues tradition. The speaker's journey from darkness to light, from blindness to vision, and the motto "merit, not sympathy, wins" reflects the blues ethos of overcoming hardship through artistic expression.
